docs.lead_paragraph: Merck-Medco Managed Care Inc., a unit of Merck & Company, said today that it had filed an antitrust suit against four pharmacy retailers in Baltimore. The suit, filed against the Rite Aid Corporation, Giant Food Inc., Neighbor Care Pharmacies Inc. and Epic Pharmacy Network Inc., charges there was an illegal antitrust conspiracy in a December 1995 boycott of the Maryland state employees' and retirees' prescription drug benefit program.

headline.main: Unit of Merck Files a Suit

docs.lead_paragraph: The future of health care in the New York region, industry analysts say, is an airy, gleaming building on Union Square that looks like a medical mall: pediatrics on 2, orthopedics and internal medicine on 3, coffee shop on 1, and glass-walled waiting rooms looking out on an atrium with a waterfall. The Phillips Ambulatory Care Center, opened last month by Beth Israel Medical Center, houses all of the hospital's outpatient services in cozy offices with plush waiting areas and state-of-the-art examining rooms. Health care experts are calling it a model for the city and the region, where outpatient, or ambulatory, care is booming.

headline.main: Region's Hospitals Have Seen the Future, and It's an Outpatient Clinic

docs.snippet: The future of health care in the New York region, industry analysts say, is an airy, gleaming building on Union Square that looks like a medical mall: pediatrics on 2, orthopedics and internal medicine on 3, coffee shop on 1, and glass-walled waiting...

docs.lead_paragraph: None of the campaigns are working. Millions are being spent on inane and annoying ads, and the candidates are dutifully tramping through the snow and the bitter cold, proffering one false promise after another (like compulsive salesmen who couldn't stop peddling their discredited wares, even if they wanted to), all for naught. Tomorrow's G.O.P. primary vote will be an exercise in futility. It won't matter who wins. No one from this group of flim-flam artists and charm school dropouts can satisfy the growing hunger among American voters for a President who will honestly and aggressively address the economic difficulties that are steadily eroding the quality of life for working men and women.

docs.lead_paragraph: Through the darkest days of the recession in the late 1980's and early 1990's, there was a certain tenet of faith in the New York region: Like the seasons, the business cycle was eternal, and when the downturn was over old-fashioned growth would return. For most of the country, that is exactly what happened. In one year of recovery, 1992 to 1993, the nation as a whole recovered all the jobs lost in the recession and even gained a few more.

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: THE net worth of black families is "just 10 percent that of white families," Worth magazine says in its March issue as it proceeds to describe a black man out to fill the financial chasm between the two races. He is Kelvin Boston, who is the host of a PBS program on personal finance and who wrote "Smart Money Moves for African-Americans," published Jan. 3 by G. P. Putnam's Sons. The brief portrait might have been less glowing than it is if Worth's editors had looked into Mr. Boston's past or had a chance to read an article on him in The Detroit News on Jan. 21.

headline.main: When a Portrait Doesn't Include the Wrinkles

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Joseph I. Kramer took early retirement. Ninety minutes early. Dr. Kramer, 71, had decided to close his pay-what-you-can-afford solo practice for good at 6 P.M. on Feb. 9. Shortly after 4, trouble walked in: a patient he first treated in an infant clinic at Bellevue Hospital 24 years ago and has treated regularly since.

docs.lead_paragraph: AS Prof. Giles Scofield of Pace Law School in White Plains sees it, "The savings and loan scandal will look like a day at Disneyland compared to today's health care crisis." Professor Scofield, a lawyer, is director of the school's Health Law and Policy Program. He recognizes that if America is to provide universal access to health care, then all services cannot be provided to all people. Finding the right balance, he concedes, is not easy.

docs.lead_paragraph: THAT Friday night five years ago when a van rolled to the curb and half a dozen process servers bearing stacks of 200-page legal papers climbed out still grips the minds of people at the Acropolis, a 16-building co-op near the towers of the Triborough Bridge in Astoria, Queens. Making their way home from work that crisp March evening, residents of the five-story walkups ringing a slim courtyard on Ditmars Boulevard had no notion that for years those legal papers would hang over their heads, their bank accounts and their sense of security.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal advisory panel appointed by the Clinton Administration plans to recommend a radical change in policy for Social Security: investing billions of dollars of payroll contributions in the stock market. The panel, whose proposed recommendations appear in a confidential draft of a report to be issued this spring, is also discussing whether payroll tax revenue for Social Security should be kept in one big pool, as it is now, or whether some should be diverted to individual accounts, so workers could invest it in stocks and bonds of their choosing.

headline.main: Plan Would Have Social Security Put Some Money in Stock Market
